intro.title: Kotlin Introduction
paragraphs: Kotlin is a modern, trending programming language that was released in 2016 by JetBrains.
It has become very popular since it is compatible with Java (one of the most popular programming languages out there), which means that Java code (and libraries) can be used in Kotlin programs.

sections.heading: What is Kotlin used for?
paragraphs: Kotlin is used for:

sections.heading: Why Use Kotlin?
list: Kotlin is fully compatible with Java
Kotlin works on different platforms (Windows, Mac, Linux, Raspberry Pi, etc.)
Kotlin is easy to learn, especially if you already know Java

sections.heading: Get Started
paragraphs: This tutorial will teach you the very basics of Kotlin.
It is not necessary to have any prior programming experience.
Get Started »

get-started.title: Kotlin Get Started
paragraphs: The easiest way to get started with Kotlin, is to use an IDE.
An IDE (Integrated Development Environment) is used to edit and compile code.
In this chapter, we will use IntelliJ (developed by the same people that created Kotlin) which is free to download from https://www.jetbrains.com/idea/download/.

sections.heading: Kotlin Install
paragraphs: Once IntelliJ is downloaded and installed, click on the New Project button to get started with IntelliJ.
Then click on "Kotlin" in the left side menu, and enter a name for your project.
Next, we need to install something called JDK (Java Development Kit) to get our Kotlin project up and going.
Click on the "Project JDK" menu, select "Download JDK" and select a version and vendor (e.g. AdoptOpenJDK 11) and click on the "Download" button.
When the JDK is downloaded and installed, choose it from the select menu and then click on the "Next" button and at last "Finish".

sections.heading: Create a Kotlin File
paragraphs: Now we can start working with our Kotlin project.
Open the src (source) folder, and create a Kotlin file.
Select the "File" option and add a name to your Kotlin file, for example "Main".

comments.title: Kotlin Comments
paragraphs: Comments can be used to explain Kotlin code, and to make it more readable.
It can also be used to prevent execution when testing alternative code.

sections.heading: Single-line Comments
paragraphs: Single-line comments starts with two forward slashes (//).
Any text between // and the end of the line is ignored by Kotlin (will not be executed).
This example uses a single-line comment before a line of code:
sections.example:
// This is a comment
println("Hello World")

sections.heading: Single-line Comment at the End of a Line
paragraphs: This example uses a single-line comment at the end of a line of code:
sections.example: println("Hello World")  // This is a comment

sections.heading: Multi-line Comments
paragraphs: Multi-line comments start with /* and ends with */.
Any text between /* and */ will be ignored by Kotlin.
This example uses a multi-line comment (a comment block) to explain the code:

variables.title: Kotlin Variables
paragraphs: Variables are containers for storing data values.
To create a variable, use var or val, and assign a value to it with the equal sign (=):

sections.heading: Syntax
sections.code:
var variableName = value
val variableName = value

sections.heading: Example
sections.example:
var name = "John"
val birthyear = 1975

println(name)          // Print the value of name
println(birthyear)     // Print the value of birthyear

sections.heading: var vs val
paragraphs: The difference between var and val is that variables declared with the var keyword can be changed/modified, while val variables cannot.

sections.heading: Variable Type
paragraphs: Unlike many other programming languages, variables in Kotlin do not need to be declared with a specified type (like "String" for text or "Int" for numbers, if you are familiar with those).
Kotlin is smart enough to understand that "John" is a String (text), and that 1975 is an Int (number) variable.
examples:
var name = "John"      // String (text)
val birthyear = 1975   // Int (number)

println(name)          // Print the value of name
println(birthyear)     // Print the value of birthyear

var name: String = "John" // String
val birthyear: Int = 1975 // Int

println(name)
println(birthyear)

sections.heading: Declare Without Value
paragraphs: You can also declare a variable without assigning the value, and assign the value later.
However, this is only possible when you specify the type:

sections.heading: Note
paragraphs: You will learn more about Data Types in the next chapter.

sections.heading: Notes on val
paragraphs: When you create a variable with the val keyword, the value cannot be changed/reassigned.
The following example will generate an error:
sections.example:
val name = "John"
name = "Robert"  // Error (Val cannot be reassigned)
println(name)

sections.heading: Changing Values with var
paragraphs: When using var, you can change the value whenever you want:
sections.example:
var name = "John"
name = "Robert"
println(name)

sections.heading: So When To Use val?
paragraphs: The val keyword is useful when you want a variable to always store the same value, like PI (3.14159...):
sections.example:
val pi = 3.14159265359
println(pi)

sections.heading: Display Variables
paragraphs: Like you have seen with the examples above, the println() method is often used to display variables.
To combine both text and a variable, use the + character:
examples:
val firstName = "John "
val lastName = "Doe"
val fullName = firstName + lastName
println(fullName)

val x = 5
val y = 6
println(x + y) // Print the value of x + y

sections.heading: From the example above, you can expect:
list: Then we use the println() method to display the value of x + y, which is 11

sections.heading: Variable Names
paragraphs: A variable can have a short name (like x and y) or more descriptive names (age, sum, totalVolume).
The general rule for Kotlin variables are:
list: Names can contain letters, digits, underscores, and dollar signs
Names should start with a letter
Names can also begin with $ and _ (but we will not use it in this tutorial)
Names are case sensitive ("myVar" and "myvar" are different variables)
Names should start with a lowercase letter and it cannot contain whitespace
Reserved words (like Kotlin keywords, such as var or String) cannot be used as names

sections.heading: camelCase variables
paragraphs: You might notice that we used firstName and lastName as variable names in the example above, instead of firstname and lastname.

This is called "camelCase", and it is considered as good practice as it makes it easier to read when you have a variable name with different words in it, for example "myFavoriteFood", "rateActionMovies" etc.

data-types.title: Kotlin Data Types
paragraphs: In Kotlin, the type of a variable is decided by its value:

sections.heading: Example
sections.example:
val myNum = 5             // Int
val myDoubleNum = 5.99    // Double
val myLetter = 'D'        // Char
val myBoolean = true      // Boolean
val myText = "Hello"      // String

sections.heading: Specify Type
paragraphs: However, you learned from the previous chapter that it is possible to specify the type if you want:
sections.example:
val myNum: Int = 5                // Int
val myDoubleNum: Double = 5.99    // Double
val myLetter: Char = 'D'          // Char
val myBoolean: Boolean = true     // Boolean
val myText: String = "Hello"      // String

sections.heading: Note
paragraphs: Sometimes you have to specify the type, and often you don't.
Anyhow, it is good to know what the different types represent.
You will learn more about when you need to specify the type later.

sections.heading: Data Type Groups
paragraphs: Data types are divided into different groups:

sections.heading: Numbers
paragraphs: Number types are divided into two groups:
Integer types store whole numbers, positive or negative (such as 123 or -456), without decimals. Valid types are Byte, Short, Int and Long.
Floating point types represent numbers with a fractional part, containing one or more decimals. There are two types: Float and Double.
If you don't specify the type for a numeric variable, it is most often returned as Int for whole numbers and Double for floating point numbers.

subsections.title: Byte
paragraphs: The Byte data type can store whole numbers from -128 to 127.
This can be used instead of Int or other integer types to save memory when you are certain that the value will be within -128 and 127:

subsections.title: Short
paragraphs: The Short data type can store whole numbers from -32768 to 32767:

subsections.title: Int
paragraphs: The Int data type can store whole numbers from -2147483648 to 2147483647:

subsections.title: Long
paragraphs: The Long data type can store whole numbers from -9223372036854775808 to 9223372036854775807.
This is used when Int is not large enough to store the value.
Optionally, you can end the value with an "L":

sections.heading: Difference Between Int and Long
paragraphs: A whole number is an Int as long as it is up to 2147483647.
If it goes beyond that, it is defined as Long:
sections.example:
val myNum1 = 2147483647  // Int
val myNum2 = 2147483648  // Long

sections.heading: Floating Point Types
paragraphs: Floating point types represent numbers with a decimal, such as 9.99 or 3.14515.
The Float and Double data types can store fractional numbers:

sections.heading: Use Float or Double?
paragraphs: The precision of a floating point value indicates how many digits the value can have after the decimal point.
The precision of Float is only six or seven decimal digits, while Double variables have a precision of about 15 digits.
Therefore it is safer to use Double for most calculations.
Also note that you should end the value of a Float type with an "F".

sections.heading: Scientific Numbers
paragraphs: A floating point number can also be a scientific number with an "e" or "E" to indicate the power of 10:
sections.example:
val myNum1: Float = 35E3F
val myNum2: Double = 12E4
println(myNum1)
println(myNum2)

sections.heading: Booleans
paragraphs: The Boolean data type can only take the values true or false:
sections.example:
val isKotlinFun: Boolean = true
val isFishTasty: Boolean = false
println(isKotlinFun)   // Outputs true
println(isFishTasty)   // Outputs false
sections.note: Boolean values are mostly used for conditional testing, which you will learn more about in a later chapter.

sections.heading: Characters
paragraphs: The Char data type is used to store a single character.
A char value must be surrounded by single quotes, like 'A' or 'c':
sections.example:
val myGrade: Char = 'B'
println(myGrade)

sections.heading: Char Note
paragraphs: Unlike Java, you cannot use ASCII values to display certain characters.
The value 66 would output a "B" in Java, but will generate an error in Kotlin:
sections.example:
val myLetter: Char = 66
println(myLetter) // Error

sections.heading: Strings
paragraphs: The String data type is used to store a sequence of characters (text).
String values must be surrounded by double quotes:
sections.example:
val myText: String = "Hello World"
println(myText)
sections.note: You will learn more about strings in the Strings chapter.

sections.heading: Arrays
paragraphs: Arrays are used to store multiple values in a single variable, instead of declaring separate variables for each value.
You will learn more about arrays in the Arrays chapter.

sections.heading: Type Conversion
paragraphs: Type conversion is when you convert the value of one data type to another type.
In Kotlin, numeric type conversion is different from Java.
For example, it is not possible to convert an Int type to a Long type with the following code:
sections.example:
val x: Int = 5
val y: Long = x
println(y) // Error: Type mismatch

sections.heading: Convert Numeric Types
paragraphs: To convert a numeric data type to another type, you must use one of the following functions:
toByte(), toShort(), toInt(), toLong(), toFloat(), toDouble() or toChar():
sections.example:
val x: Int = 5
val y: Long = x.toLong()
println(y)

operators.title: Kotlin Operators
paragraphs: Operators are used to perform operations on variables and values.
The value is called an operand, while the operation (to be performed between the two operands) is defined by an operator:

sections.heading: Operands and Operators
paragraphs: In the example below, the numbers 100 and 50 are operands, and the + sign is an operator:

sections.heading: Operator with Variables
paragraphs: Although the + operator is often used to add together two values, it can also be used to add together a variable and a value, or a variable and a variable:

sections.heading: Operator Groups
paragraphs: Kotlin divides the operators into the following groups:

sections.heading: Arithmetic Operators
paragraphs: Arithmetic operators are used to perform common mathematical operations.

sections.heading: Kotlin Assignment Operators
paragraphs: Assignment operators are used to assign values to variables.
In the example below, we use the assignment operator (=) to assign the value 10 to a variable called x:
sections.example: var x = 10

sections.heading: Addition Assignment Operator (+=)
paragraphs: The addition assignment operator (+=) adds a value to a variable:
sections.example:
var x = 10
x += 5

sections.heading: Kotlin Comparison Operators
paragraphs: Comparison operators are used to compare two values, and returns a Boolean value: either true or false.
sections.note: You will learn much more about Booleans in the Boolean chapter and Conditions.

sections.heading: Kotlin Logical Operators
paragraphs: Logical operators are used to determine the logic between variables or values:

rows: Returns true if both statements are true
Returns true if one of the statements is true
Reverse the result, returns false if the result is true

strings.title: Kotlin Strings
paragraphs: Strings are used for storing text.
A string contains a collection of characters surrounded by double quotes:

sections.heading: Example
sections.example: var greeting = "Hello"

sections.heading: String Type
paragraphs: Unlike Java, you do not have to specify that the variable should be a String.
Kotlin is smart enough to understand that the greeting variable in the example above is a String because of the double quotes.
However, just like with other data types, you can specify the type if you insist:
sections.example: var greeting: String = "Hello"

sections.heading: Note
paragraphs: If you want to create a String without assigning the value (and assign the value later), you must specify the type while declaring the variable:

sections.heading: Access a String
paragraphs: To access the characters (elements) of a string, you must refer to the index number inside square brackets.
String indexes start with 0.
In the example below, we access the first and third element in txt:
sections.example:
var txt = "Hello World"
println(txt[0]) // first element (H)
println(txt[2]) // third element (l)
sections.note: [0] is the first element. [1] is the second element, [2] is the third element, etc.

sections.heading: String Length
paragraphs: A String in Kotlin is an object, which contain properties and functions that can perform certain operations on strings, by writing a dot character (.) after the specific string variable.
For example, the length of a string can be found with the length property:
sections.example:
var txt = "ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ"
println("The length of the txt string is: " + txt.length)

sections.heading: String Functions
paragraphs: There are many string functions available, for example uppercase() and lowercase():
sections.example:
var txt = "Hello World"
println(txt.uppercase())   // Outputs "HELLO WORLD"
println(txt.lowercase())   // Outputs "hello world"

sections.heading: Comparing Strings
paragraphs: The compareTo(string) function compares two strings and returns 0 if both are equal:
sections.example:
var txt1 = "Hello World"
var txt2 = "Hello World"
println(txt1.compareTo(txt2))  // Outputs 0 (they are equal)

sections.heading: Finding a String in a String
paragraphs: The indexOf() function returns the index (the position) of the first occurrence of a specified text in a string (including whitespace):
sections.example:
var txt = "Please locate where 'locate' occurs!"
println(txt.indexOf("locate"))  // Outputs 7
sections.note: Remember that Kotlin counts positions from zero. 0 is the first position in a string, 1 is the second, 2 is the third ...

sections.heading: Quotes Inside a String
paragraphs: To use quotes inside a string, use single quotes ('):
sections.example:
var txt1 = "It's alright"
var txt2 = "That's great"

sections.heading: String Concatenation
paragraphs: The + operator can be used between strings to add them together to make a new string. This is called concatenation:
sections.example:
var firstName = "John"
var lastName = "Doe"
println(firstName + " " + lastName)
sections.note: Note that we have added an empty text (" ") to create a space between firstName and lastName on print.

sections.heading: Concatenate with plus()
paragraphs: You can also use the plus() function to concatenate two strings:
sections.example:
var firstName = "John "
var lastName = "Doe"
println(firstName.plus(lastName))

sections.heading: String Templates/Interpolation
paragraphs: Instead of concatenation, you can also use "string templates", which is an easy way to add variables and expressions inside a string.
Just refer to the variable with the $ symbol:
sections.example:
var firstName = "John"
var lastName = "Doe"
println("My name is $firstName $lastName")
sections.note: "String Templates" is a popular feature of Kotlin, as it reduces the amount of code.

booleans.title: Kotlin Booleans
paragraphs: Very often, in programming, you will need a data type that can only have one of two values, like:
YES / NO
ON / OFF
TRUE / FALSE
For this, Kotlin has a Boolean data type, which can take the values true or false.

sections.heading: Boolean Values
paragraphs: A boolean type can be declared with the Boolean keyword and can only take the values true or false:
sections.example:
val isKotlinFun: Boolean = true
val isFishTasty: Boolean = false
println(isKotlinFun)   // Outputs true
println(isFishTasty)   // Outputs false

sections.heading: Boolean Without Specifying Type
paragraphs: Just like you have learned with other data types in the previous chapters, the example above can also be written without specifying the type, as Kotlin is smart enough to understand that the variables are Booleans:
sections.example:
val isKotlinFun = true
val isFishTasty = false
println(isKotlinFun)   // Outputs true
println(isFishTasty)   // Outputs false

sections.heading: Boolean Expression
paragraphs: A Boolean expression returns a Boolean value: true or false.
You can use a comparison operator, such as the greater than (>) operator to find out if an expression (or a variable) is true:
sections.example:
val x = 10
val y = 9
println(x > y) // Returns true, because 10 is greater than 9

sections.heading: Example
paragraphs: Or even easier:
sections.example: println(10 > 9) // Returns true, because 10 is greater than 9

sections.heading: Equal To Operator (==)
paragraphs: In the examples below, we use the equal to (==) operator to evaluate an expression:
examples:
val x = 10;
println(x == 10); // Returns true, because the value of x is equal to 10
println(10 == 15); // Returns false, because 10 is not equal to 15

sections.heading: Note
paragraphs: The Boolean value of an expression is the basis for all Kotlin comparisons and conditions.
You will learn more about conditions in the next chapter.

if-else.title: Kotlin Conditions and If..Else
paragraphs: You already know that Kotlin supports familiar comparison conditions from mathematics, such as:
Less than: a < b
Less than or equal to: a <= b
Greater than: a > b
Greater than or equal to: a >= b
Equal to a == b
Not Equal to: a != b
You can use these conditions to perform different actions for different decisions.
Kotlin has the following conditionals:

sections.heading: Conditionals
list: Use if to specify a block of code to be executed, if a specified condition is true
Use else to specify a block of code to be executed, if the same condition is false
Use else if to specify a new condition to test, if the first condition is false
Use when to specify many alternative blocks of code to be executed

sections.heading: Note
paragraphs: Unlike Java, if..else can be used as a statement or as an expression (to assign a value to a variable) in Kotlin.

sections.heading: Kotlin if
paragraphs: Use if to specify a block of code to be executed if a condition is true.
sections.note: Note that if is in lowercase letters. Uppercase letters (If or IF) will generate an error.

sections.heading: Example explained
paragraphs: In the example above we use two variables, x and y, to test whether x is greater than y (using the > operator).
As x is 20, and y is 18, and we know that 20 is greater than 18, we print to the screen that "x is greater than y".

sections.heading: Kotlin else
paragraphs: Use else to specify a block of code to be executed if the condition is false.

sections.heading: Example explained
paragraphs: In the example above, time (20) is greater than 18, so the condition is false, so we move on to the else condition and print to the screen "Good evening".
If the time was less than 18, the program would print "Good day".

sections.heading: Kotlin else if
paragraphs: Use else if to specify a new condition if the first condition is false.

sections.heading: Example explained (else if)
paragraphs: In the example above, time (22) is greater than 10, so the first condition is false.
The next condition, in the else if statement, is also false, so we move on to the else condition since condition1 and condition2 is both false - and print to the screen "Good evening".
However, if the time was 14, our program would print "Good day."
